segments.text: I believe that the word that you used was interrelating these ideas.
Would you just say a few words about that, please?
Right.

Well, for example, if we look at aspects of the marine environment, take this thing I'm thinking about right now, ocean disposal of dredged material, we can analyze the water column for the metals contained as normal background and then look at it from the standpoint of
the metals being introduced, which could be toxic to marine organisms.
And we can then look at the nature of the water itself and the effect it's having on these metals, oxidizing them.
Do they become more or less stable?
And we can take all of the pieces apart and enumerate these.
But it isn't until we attempt to say what does this all mean and try to put it together into a working system that we really feel we're achieving anything today.
And this is what I call synthesis.
OK. Another question I have is with reference to your discussion of the potential of the ocean.
Is the biological potential of the ocean really as low as you say?
For instance, as you say, it's an auxiliary spinoff from the land.
Is our ocean technology advanced enough yet really to accurately predict the future of the marine food production in the future?
Take, for example, the lush production that we have in parts of Israel once we had a desert.
In other words, are we at a stage where we can really say what the potential will be?
And so when you're talking about the potential of the ocean being low, are you talking about long range or in the short range?
Well, for example, I'm talking about long range, I think.
I'm talking about the ultimate.
That's my opinion.
Now, it is an opinion.
It's certainly not a fact.
But if you want to take the time yourself to look at an analysis of mid-Pacific water and try to decide what nutrients are there and what could be sustained by those nutrients,

knowing what the relationship is between phosphate say and the amount of material you can build of an organism and if you've got something on the way of exchange rates for this material from the deeper water i think you can calculate what it could produce and it turns out it's not as much as you might want to think now
I'll admit, there is a giant mid-Pacific gyre where this slow-moving stuff is going around.
And probably not as much exchange as we'd like to believe.
But it is for reasons of this type, taking that nature is an omniscient object,

kind of not only innovator but operator in a sense it's an opportunist it takes advantage of what is there to build more I think this is the whole basis for evolution as a matter of fact progressive evolution I think the only way you can define it is organisms that have found a way to utilize matter and energy that hasn't been utilized up to then
And as a consequence, I think that the same is true here, that you would expect if nature could do it, it would have done it by now.
And it's not producing very much there.
Now, that is what I'm basing it on.
It may be awfully shaky ground, but I simply feel that it's
just not advisable to hold out this hope to people that there is going to be a millennium when we can harvest the sea effectively.
I can't see how you wall it off.
And I can see you could do it.
But Lord, the output of energy and materials would be so great that the return would be meaningless.
I think the land is still the place.
Oh, I'd love to think it could do more.
And indeed, it can do more.
But I do not believe for its area that it will ever produce as effectively as the land.
OK.
Thank you.
I'd like to go on to a different topic now.

In terms of systematics, what is your opinion of the new definition of families, genera, and species which are evolving based on mathematical indices such as the percent similarity index and these kinds of indices as opposed to the classical morphological approach to systematics?
All right.
I consider these
to systematics about as I would the microscope to optics.
All these things do is extend one's penetration into the subject.
But it still leaves judgment as the basis for decision making.
And I do not believe that you can find
a mathematical or numerical system that will ever replace it.
Now, I believe these are important tools, and I believe they give us insights.
But, for example, I was examining about 400 species of organisms living on the continental slope.

trying to look at their distributions, ordering their distributions vertically, bathymetrically, so to speak, and determining whether or not they actually were sort of living in assemblages or communities, in the very loose sense of the term.
And I came up with certain clusters.
Now, there are statistical methods for finding these clusters, and we didn't vary at all.
If it's set up, it saves a lot of time to go through the statistical approach.
And it's very nice as a corroboration verification.
But I think you still have to have the judgment, because it's man's mind that made the system in the first place.
Sure, I believe these are good tools.
But just as the microscope extends your vision into this subject,
and permits your senses to probe a little more deeply into it.
So these systems permit you to grasp, perhaps, relationships you didn't see as easily.
But I still think you have to make up the mind as to what the decision will be after you do it.
Is it a new species or not?
What percentage similarity should there be?
What should the ratio be to be significant?
Arbitrarily, there would be an assumption
It's got to be over 50% or 30% is enough, okay?
I think this is true.
Now, certainly I think, though, that there's some splendid statistical treatments today for ecological science.
And we are using those very extensively in my work with the myofuna.
And I think that it's there that
Some people, now certainly there are not many, but some people get the idea that cause and effect can be approached through statistics.
It can, but it can't prove it, that there is a cause and effect.
You can get a high correlation between this and this, and you'd like to think, God, this causes this,
But that statistics never tells you that.
You've still got to make up your own mind, is it or not.
And some of it's just plain garbage, you know, when you come out of it.
You know it's garbage that the computer has given you.
It says, hey, look, you've got a beautiful relationship here.
But that's all it is, just a relationship.
There's no causation involved.
It took me a little time to think of that.
I figured out that...
Boy, you just fall right into that trap, though.
So human judgment is the ultimate...
I think so.
It's a magnificent thing.
I wish politicians used it more.
We'd like for you to evaluate for us what you consider the significance of the work you've done in the field of family organisms.
Fouling organism?
Oh.
Well, I'll tell you.
I'll take an approach to that that's unorthodox.
The only thing we did was an ad hoc study, or ad hoc if you want,
of fouling in one area of the Gulf of Mexico.

And we did it because of the need for the Navy to know at the time what kinds and how many following organisms would develop on various pieces of equipment they might wish to put out into the ocean and how long it would take before they were fouled up.
And so we did that.
And we came up with some answers.

which seemed to be satisfactory, and they needed to know whether one particular antifoulant, which was relatively new then, which was an organotin compound, whether or not this would work to protect the devices where fouling would be a major problem.
Okay.
Now, however, as a result of that study, I think, although...
It is not as well received.
The important thing was how much fouling organisms, so-called, can tell us about the marine environment.
And the reason we call them fouling organisms is because they are growing on surfaces that man doesn't want them to grow on.
artificial surfaces, ships, docks, buoys.
It's like dirt.
A flower and a cake is magnificent, but on the floor it's dirt.
And the same is true of the following organism.
Now, I became convinced that these were magnificent current meters.
They were magnificent markers of
of water masses, and that they could tell us a great deal about the movement of water.
Because if you put something out for these pelagic larvae of these organisms to settle on as they're being carried by the water, if one settles on this piece of stuff you've got out there,
and you see it there, and you know that it only exists in a certain water mass, then you can demonstrate that water mass was there.
However, to go out and sample it with temperature and salinity probes to determine the water mass would take thousands of dollars and many hours of time to watch.
So I figured here was a nice little cheap way of learning an immense amount about the marine environment.
For example, if you had, say, this is Yucatan, and you're coming up north, the loop current and so on.
And this is the Yucatan Peninsula, and this is Cuba over here, and Florida coming down over here.

If you know that an organism as adults only lives here and it's producing larvae and they come in here, and if you have a device up here on which they can settle and nothing in between they can settle on, then you can not only determine that the larvae are being carried this far, but you can also determine something about their life cycle and a lot of other intellectual things.
So I think that's important to me.
We'll get around to convincing more people, but I never did go on with it because we got involved in deep sea work and I couldn't go on.
So, the significance?
Well, just an ad hoc thing for the Navy on that one thing, but I think that the use of these organisms is important.
Now, let me say this, that a fellow by the name of Shaltima at Woods Hole has done an immense amount with
the transport of pelagic larvae across the entire Atlantic Ocean.
And we now know that there is the potential for larvae produced in Europe to be transported in the north equatorial current across to the Americas.
I don't know if they can get through to the shore, but they're out there, not very far away.

What do you think of the concept of bringing the sea to the land, that is, the development of marine organisms in artificial environments of land, if you should like, like Spillhouse's concept of inland dream cities?
Well, I think this is a real promising thing, and I think it's starting right now in West Texas.
You know, there are salt domes.
in West Texas, and I think this looks like an interesting development to me to try to raise shrimp out in West Texas around Van Horn.
That'd be kind of fascinating.
Sure, I think this is real, and I think it's a good possibility.
Could this possibly be then one of the keys of ocean success to population expansion in the future?
Well, I think it's...
it's a move in that direction.

The difficulty is that most of the things we, we want to culture, uh, almost, uh, end up in the gourmet food category, you know, and I don't think that's going to feed the world, but I'm sure it's an interesting supplement and, and a worthwhile supplement economically.
I think it's sound.
I think it's going to extend, uh, agriculture a bit.
I think it's going to be as important as the, uh, as the fish pond of China.
And, uh,
more and more will be important.
However, it is going to have to be geographically limited because there are not that many places you can get good saline water in inland.
Mariculture is a real hope to provide the frosting on the cake, I think.
Now, what do you intend to be your next project?
Well, I don't know.
My interest right now is, of course, consulting with industry, trying to determine whether or not we can make compatible use of the sea, multiple use of the sea.
That's one reason we're having this symposium on the Continental Shelf, because of multiple use.
When I go to St. Croix next week, it's because of a public hearing on putting an offshore terminal on the south shore of a beautiful island.
Should it be done or shouldn't it be done?
And I think I'm one that likes to look at trade-offs.
You win a little and lose a little.
I'm afraid I have to say that I consider man to be an important part of the world's ecosystem and that we've got to fulfill his needs.
And I guess at the same time, I'm guided by one other thing, is that I'm generally not so concerned about what man does in the marine environment, but how he does it.
He's pretty sloppy at times.
Now, as for the next project, okay, it is to produce a book along with Darnell on the continental shelves of the United States, which we hope will be the definitive book on the continental shelf.
And by definitive, I mean that it will do for research and knowledge of the continental shelf what the book on estuaries did
years ago, several years ago, as a result of a Sapelo Island conference.
And we are going to produce that book within the year, I think.
That, to me, is going to be a major undertaking.
And so that's enough to keep me happy right now.
There are a lot of research activities.
I'm working on two major research activities through the university.
for the Bureau of Land Management on the myofauna, these minute little organisms that live in the sediments.
And so I've got enough to do there.
I've got six students working for me on that project right now.
And I'm going to report on that in this symposium, as a matter of fact.
So I would say what I'm trying to do there is produce an indicator
of the importance of fouling or pollution from the extraction of oil and really attempt to find the answer to what it's doing in the environment.
We've got an immense amount of work that's been done in the laboratory on petroleum pollution, but we have very little that's been done in the field.
We've come up with a method of assaying that.
And I have been invited by the USGS to consider entering into a big activity with them in September because of this little method we've come up with.
So I guess that's about it.
